stem: A 68-year-old patient reports dizziness and arm fatigue when exercising the left upper limb. On exam, the left radial pulse diminishes with active abduction and external rotation. Blood pressure is 25 mmHg lower in the left arm than the right. Which artery is stenosed?

choices.B: Axillary artery distal to the first rib
choices.C: Brachial artery proximal to the elbow

rationale_correct: Subclavian steal syndrome occurs when proximal subclavian stenosis diverts vertebral flow, causing arm claudication and diminished pulses during exertion.

rationale_distractors.B: Distal axillary lesions reduce pulses without vertebrobasilar symptoms.
rationale_distractors.C: Brachial artery stenosis affects distal perfusion but not vertebrobasilar flow.
rationale_distractors.D: Radial artery disease causes localized hand ischemia without systemic steal.
rationale_distractors.E: Common carotid stenosis causes cerebral hypoperfusion but not arm claudication.
